turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I really shouldn't have any more. I'm a little tipsy already.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm trying to get you to stay for dinner. We're going to have a lot of roast left over.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I couldn't possibly. I have to get back.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Cheers.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Cheers.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What's in this? Nitro-glycerin?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Why do you have to rush off? What's so important in San Francisco?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well... I have to get to work tomorrow morning, for one thing.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You have a job?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I have several jobs.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What do you do?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I do different things on different days.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: On Mondays and Wednesdays, I work for the Travelers' Aid. At the airport.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Helping travelers.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And on Tuesdays, I take a course in General Semantics at Berkeley.  That's not a job, of course. I just take it because...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What about Thursdays and Fridays?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: On Thursdays I have my meeting and lunch.  I'm chairman of a group that's sending a little Korean boy through school. We plan how to raise funds and... things like that.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: And Fridays? What do you do then?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Nothing.  I go to bird shops on Fridays.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm glad you do.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Do you know what I was doing in that shop?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I have an aunt, you see. Aunt Tessa. She's seventy years old, and veddy prim and strait-laced.  She's coming back from Europe at the end of the month, and I'm going to give her a myna bird that'll talk to her.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What'll it say?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You'll think me very bold, sir.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No, tell me.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You look a little shaken.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I... I am.  Mitch, is... Mitch, this isn't usual, is it? The gull yesterday when I was in the boat, and the one last night at Annie's, and now...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Last night? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: A gull smashed into Annie's front door.  Mitch... what's happening?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know, Melanie.  Look, do you have to go back to Annie's?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, I have my things in the car.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Then stay and have something to eat before you start back. I'd feel a lot better.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you want some mustard with this?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Some cream?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'll get it.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'll take Cathy up to bed.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Are you staying?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think I should, don't you?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It smelled of the fire.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It's hard to believe anything at all happened yesterday, isn't it? It's so beautiful and still now.  I think I've got it all figured out, by the way.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Really? Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It's an uprising.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Of birds?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Certainly, of birds.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It all started several months ago with a peasant sparrow up in the hills, a malcontent. He went around telling all the other sparrows that human beings weren't fit to rule this planet, preaching wherever anyone would listen...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Growing a beard...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, of course, he had to have a beard! 'Birds of the world, unite!' he kept saying, over and over...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: So they united.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Not at first. Oh yes, a few sparrows out for kicks...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Well, they'll go along with anything.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Sure. But eventually, even the more serious-minded birds began to listen. "Why should humans rule?" they asked themselves.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Hear!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why should we submit ourselves to their domination?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Hear, hear!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And all the while, that sparrow was getting in his little messages. Birds of the world, unite!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Take wing!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You have nothing to lose but your feathers.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What it was, probably...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Mmm?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: They're probably hungry, that's all. This was a bad summer. They eat berries and... and nuts, you know, and the hills are all burned out, so they're probably searching for food wherever they can get it.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: With my little sparrow leading team.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It's so damn quiet out there.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It was like that yesterday.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: After the gulls attacked.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I hadn't thought of that.  And then the swifts came.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It makes you feel as if they're... they're waiting or... resting... or....

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No, they're having a meeting, Melanie. Your sparrow is standing on a soap box and...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Melanie, Melanie...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm frightened, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No, no...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm frightened and confused and I... I think I want to go back to San Francisco where there are buildings and... and concrete and...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Melanie...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: ...everything I know.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That was Al on the phone. He wants me to meet him out at the Fawcett place. Says some detectives from Santa Rosa'll be there in a little while.  Will you be all right here?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes. I was just taking her in some tea.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I got here as fast as I could. Where's Cathy?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: At Annie's house. She's all right.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think it's safe to get out now.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Don't let's take any chances.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We've got to get Cathy.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The town looks clear.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: The bay doesn't.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How long have they been gathering there?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: The past fifteen minutes.  It seems to be a pattern, doesn't it? They strike and disappear, and then they start massing again.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I keep thinking of Annie.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It... it doesn't look very different, does it? A little smoke over the town, but otherwise...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Even the birds sitting out there. It does look very much the same, Mitch. This could be last week.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It may not be last week again for a long long time.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you want to try your father again?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I tried a little while ago. The phone's dead.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Have we still got power?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.  I'm tired, Mitch. I'm so very very tired.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Where are they heading?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Inland.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Santa Rosa?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: When will they stop?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I thought they'd have stopped by now.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Almost two a.m.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You must be exhausted.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: How about you?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You'd have been safe in San Francisco.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't want to be safe. I want to be with you.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: The power.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Mitch...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Wait here. Don't move.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We'd better light some of those lamps.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No... wait.  Hold me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Mitch, if they hear the car starting... if they see movement...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We'll take it slow until we get to the main road.  Are you ready?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Can we turn back?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I... I don't think so. If we get through town, I think we'll be all right.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Hello, Mrs. MacGruder, have you ever seen so many gulls?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Hello, Miss Daniels.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What do you suppose it is?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: I was hoping you'd be a little late, Miss Daniels.  You see, he hasn't arrived yet.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You said three o'clock.

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: I know. Oh, I know.  I've been calling all morning. Oh, you have no idea. Miss Daniels, they're so difficult to get, really they are. We get them from India, you know, when they're just little chicks, and then we have to...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, this one won't be a chick, will he?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Certainly not. Oh, no. Certainly not. This will be a full grown myna bird. Full grown.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And he'll talk?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Well, yes, he'll talk. Well, no, no. You'll have to teach him to talk.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Yes.  Oh my, I suppose I should call them again. They said three o'clock.  Maybe it's the traffic. I'll call. Would you mind waiting?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think maybe you'd better deliver him. Let me give you my address.

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Oh. Oh, well, all right.

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: I'm sure they're on the way, though. Could I just call?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, all right, but...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: There we are!

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Oh, good! Oh, wonderful.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That... that... who was that?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: I have no idea.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Have you got a pencil?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: What? Oh, yes, certainly.

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: They said the myna bird would be here later this afternoon. If you'd care to come back...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, you'd better send him. May I use your phone?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Yes, certainly.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Do you have any lovebirds?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: No, not in the shop. But I can order them for you.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How soon?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: Well... well, how soon would you want them?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Immediately.  Is this the Daily News? Melanie Daniels. Would you get me the city desk, please?

turns.speaker: MRS. MACGRUDER
turns.text: I might be able to have them by tomorrow morning. Would that be all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That would be just fine.  Hello, Charlie, this is Melanie. I want you to do a favor for me.  No, this is a small one.  Pressure you? Why, Charlie darling, would I try to pressure you?  Will you call the Department of Motor Vehicles for me and find out who owns this license plate? DKQ dash one seven six.  Yes, a California plate.  No, I'll stop up there in a little while. Is daddy in his office?  Oh. No, no, I don't want to break in on a meeting. Just tell him I'll see him later. Thank you, Charlie.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, the birds didn't attack until the children were outside the school. Crows, I think. I don't know, Daddy. Is there a difference between crows and blackbirds?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: There is very definitely a difference, Miss.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: They're different, Daddy.  Thank you.  I think these were crows. Yes, hundreds of them. Yes, they attacked the children, attacked them.  Daddy, a little girl was sent to the hospital in Santa Rosa. Well, all right, but you act as if I'm... all right, all right.  No, I can't come home now. I just can't, Daddy. How is it there? I mean... are there birds? In the sky? But no trouble. Well, I hope...  I don't know when. I simply can't leave now. Tell Mother not to worry. All right, Daddy, good-by.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: They're both perching birds, of course, but of quite different species. The crow is brachyrhynchos. The blackbird is cyanocephalus.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Thank you.  Do you know Dan Fawcett's number?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I just came from the school, madam. I don't know about their brain pans but...

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Birds are not aggressive creatures, Miss. They bring beauty to the world. It is mankind, rather, who...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Hello, may I speak to Mitch Brenner, please?  Yes, I'll wait.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: ...insist on making it difficult for life to survive on this planet. If it weren't for birds...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, all right, I'll wait for you. Good-by.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: I hardly think a few birds are going to bring about the end of the world.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: These weren't a few birds.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: The gulls were after your fish, Mr. Sholes. Really, let's be logical about this.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What were the crows after at the school?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: What do you think they were after, Miss...?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Daniels. I think they were after the children.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: For what purpose?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: To...  To kill them.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't know why.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: I thought not. Birds have been on this planet since archaeopteryx, Miss Daniels; a hundred and twenty million years ago!

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Doesn't it seem odd that they'd wait all that time to start a... a war against humanity?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No one called it a war!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Have you ever seen a jay protecting a nest?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: I have seen jays doing everything it is conceivable for jays to do. Ornithology happens to be my avocation, Miss Daniels. You're talking about preservation of the species, a hen protecting her young. There's a vast difference between...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Maybe they're all protecting the species. Maybe they're tired of being shot at and roasted in ovens and...

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Are you discussing gamebirds now? All birds are not gamebirds, you know.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't know anything about birds except that they're attacking this town.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: And what? Vultures? Hawks? Eagles?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Maybe! Is it impossible?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Yes. I have never known birds of different species to flock together. The very concept is unimaginable.  Why if that happened, we wouldn't have a chance. How could we possible hope to fight them?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Sebastian, I'm not an alarmist.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: No one ever said you were, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think we're in trouble. I don't know how or why this started, but I know it's here and I know we'd be crazy to ignore it.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: Look, Mitch, even if this is true, even if all the birds...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you believe it's true, Sebastian?

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: No. I don't, Mitch. Because I can't see any reason for it.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It's happening. Isn't that a good enough reason?

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: I like Bodega Bay as well as any man. If I thought...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Then help me, Sebastian. You're an important man in this town. If you'll help, the rest will.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: Help how? What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm not sure, but...

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: If you don't even know what you want to do...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I only know we've got to drive them away from town -- before they drive us away.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mrs. Bundy, you said something about Santa Cruz. About seagulls getting lost in the fog, and heading in for the lights.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: How do you plan to do that?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: With smoke.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: How can we go on living here if we blanket the town with smoke?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Can we go on living here otherwise?

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Scotch, light on the water.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: You and Mr. Sholes seem to be implying as much.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Birds?

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Yeah, birds. All they do is make a mess of everything. Who needs them?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: We need them.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Not if they're starting a war.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: They are incapable of organized warfare!

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Then fight back. Get yourselves guns and wipe them off the face of the earth.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: That would hardly be possible.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Kill them all. Get rid of them. Messy animals.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: ...probably contain more than a hundred billion birds!

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: That's right, sir, I recall it. A large flock of seagulls got lost in a fog and headed in for the town, where all the lights were.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: They made some mess, too, smashing into houses and everything.  They always make a mess. We're better off without them.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: The point is that no one seemed to get upset about it. They were gone the next morning, just as if nothing at all had happened. Poor things.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: How many gulls did you count, Mrs. Bundy?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Which gulls, Mr. Sholes? There are several varieties.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: The ones that've been raising the devil with my fishing boats.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Probably herring gulls. They arrive in November, you know, and don't migrate North again until March or...

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: Actually, those gulls must have been after the fish.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: Makes a lot more sense than... well, an attack.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Of course it does. If we believe that birds are attacking, why... why next we'll believe that grasshoppers and cockroaches are capable of...

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: I'm going out that way, lady. You can follow me.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Then let's go. Now!

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: I haven't finished my drink.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Put on your coats! Do you want to get trapped here?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Were the Santa Rosa police at your school today?  Are you coming?

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Take it easy, lady.  There isn't a bird anywhere in sight.

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: Something like this happened in Santa Cruz last year. The town was covered with seagulls.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Can't you please finish your drink?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I'm leaving! Are you coming?

turns.speaker: SALESMAN
turns.text: All right, all right!  Hope you figure this out, folks.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I'm Donald Fettes.

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: I'm very pleased to know you, Master Fettes.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Mr. Gray?

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: That's right.  Gray, the cabman. I've had a bit of dealing with MacFarlane in the past, you know.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Dr. MacFarlane said I should pay you --

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: Of course -- it's the soul of the business -- the pay --

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: I fear he may have to.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But can't you give me any idea?

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: How could I?  I will do my best. After all, you see, I am financially interested.

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: There, Master Fettes.  Sooner than we had expected.  A stoke of luck one might say.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: GRAY
turns.text: Oh, you'll have ample opportunity -- ample --  Good morning, Dr. Fettes.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: You asked to see me, ma'am?

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: I want you to help my little girl.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I'm only a student.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: Georgina told me how kind you were to her.  It gave me hope you might intercede for us with Dr. MacFarlane.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I don't know that I can do that, Mrs. Marsh.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: Did he tell you about Georgina?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I didn't mean it that way.  I meant only that I am not in a position to ask favors.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: Ask this one favor --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Of course I will.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: You have his promise, then?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: -- pain -- and shock.  She's brave enough, but I don't know about myself.  Now that it seems so close, I wonder if I dare trust my child into any but God's hands. Maybe He knows best.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Ma'am, is you'll allow me, I'd like to give you cause for courage -- Dr. MacFarlane is a great man -- I think he's the greatest man in medicine.  God would not have given him such gifts if they were not meant for Georgina's cure.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Good morning, Mrs. Marsh.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Fettes.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: It's not because of Georgina -- because of Dr. MacFarlane's failure?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: It's not the failure. I feel that MacFarlane has taught me nothing. He taught me the mathematics of anatomy but he couldn't teach me the poetry of medicine.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Even so, I could never think of going on -- I've got to find some other profession.

turns.speaker: MRS. MARSH
turns.text: It is a pity.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: You must leave this house.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I can't do that -- you heard MacFarlane.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: Save yourself. Master Fettes look at MacFarlane and be warned.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: He's a great doctor -- a great man --

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: Is it a great man whom Gray can order to his bidding? Is it a great man who for very shame dare not acknowledge his own wife so that I must play maidservant for the world's sake and his success?

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: He could have been a great man -- a good man and a fine doctor, but there was always the shame of the old life and the old ways to hold him back -- and always Gray -- Gray to hound him to his death.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: You're over-excited, Mistress Cameron.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: I'm cold as ice.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But Gray's only a cab driver -- a Resurrection Man who robs graves to make a bit of money now and again.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: If he were only that. The man's evil himself. Some day you'll know him as MacFarlane knows him -- for MacFarlane he was to Knox as you are to him. That brought him close to Gray, he roistered with him and drank with him. Aye, and Gray even brought him to my door and my love. There is all that between them and more -- Burke and Hare and Knox --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But that's long since.  Gray can't threaten him with that.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: Gray has no need to threaten. You remember the trial?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I heard my parents speak of it in Thrums. It was a famous case.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: And did you hear them speak of the porter who testified against Burke?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: They did not tell you how that porter cried out in the witness box when the Kings Counselor pressed him hard -- how he cried out that he was shielding a gentleman of consequence.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: That porter was Gray and the gentleman of consequence who couldn't swallow the shame of it -- who took my last paltry savings to hire Gray --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: MacFarlane

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: Listen to me, Fettes, I'm one part befuddled with drink, one part over-heels in love with MacFarlane, and one part fey. You're a lowlander, Fettes, and you have no way of knowing what we Highlanders call the second sight.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I've heard of it.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: It's a gift to my people -- and I see MacFarlane and Gray-- the pit yawns for them and the flames -- and I would have you away from them and safe out of the torment.--

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: He's not home.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Where can I find him?

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: You don't went to find him. Your news will keep until I tell him.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But I must tell him -- he must know of it. Please -- tell me where he is.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: There's no standing between a fool and his folly. If you must babble your news to him he's at the Fisherman's Tryst. It's the inn at Pennycuik. You can use MacFarlane's horse and gig to get there. He'll welcome the ride back.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: At Pennycuik.  I know the inn.  I can be there in an hour.

turns.speaker: MEG
turns.text: And back with MacFarlane and all that he stands for the next day.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Excuse me, Dr. MacFarlane --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Come in, boy -- come in.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But, Doctor, I only wanted to speak to you --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Come -- it's a chance to try out your bedside manner, Fettes.  Take a look at the child.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Dr. MacFarlane --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I'm afraid I'll have to give up medicine, Dr. MacFarlane.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You're made for a doctor, young man!

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I'm afraid I have to, sir.  You see, my father is vicar at Thrums -- it's a small parish -- not much of a living --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You're too good a man, Fettes -- I'll not let you quit.  I'll make an assistant of you -- that'll pay your keep and your tuition, too --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I thought only the best students were made assistants.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Well? And are you not a good student?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But Richardson?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Richardson is a fine student.  He's got a glib tongue, but you'll be a better doctor, Fettes.  Come along now --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You know how we get the specimens we use for dissection?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: From the Municipal Council -- they're the bodies of paupers --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I don't think I can go on, sir.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: What the devil do you mean?  You have your lodgings, a certain stipend -- I thought I had arranged everything for you --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I saw the woman whose son's body was delivered last night.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: And that's why you don't want to be a doctor, Fettes?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Not if I have to be party to things like that, Dr. MacFarlane.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But this woman -- and her son --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I'm sorry for the woman, Fettes. But her son might be alive today had more doctors been given the opportunity to work on more human specimens.  As for me, Fettes, I let no man stop me when I know I'm right -- when I know that I need those lifeless subjects for my student's enlightenment and for my own knowledge.  And if you're a real man and want to be a good doctor, you'll see it as I see it.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Dr. MacFarlane -- you remember the lady who came to see you yesterday -- the lady with the little girl?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I remember her.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: She came again today.  She wanted me to ask you if you would not break your rule and operate.  She feels you are her only hope.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: So she told me.  I'm a teacher -- not a practitioner.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: It was about last night I wanted to talk to you -- about the operation on the little Marsh girl.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You're a man of the world, Fettes, you wouldn't hold me to promise given in drink.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But I -- well, you see, sir, I met Mrs. Marsh and told her.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Really, Fettes, you irk me with your lack of understanding.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But you did promise.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Look here, Fettes.  Not I nor anyone else knows enough about the spinal column and its intricacies to insure success in such an operation.  I would have to study the matter.  Have we any "subjects"?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Wilmont used up the last spinal section.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You see, it is completely out of the question.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Yes, I suppose so.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Now you run off and see that pretty Mrs. Marsh and explain to her.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Every street singer with a cracked voice gives tongue to that one.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: This girl was beautiful -- a wild lassie from the Highlands.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Gray killed her.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: We can't be sure of that.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I am sure.  I mean to report it. It's like Burke and Hare all over again.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I wouldn't do that, Fettes.  I wouldn't report it.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Grave robbing is one thing -- this is murder.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I don't know that -- neither do you.  This subject may have been an epileptic -- thrown a fit -- fallen out of bed -- cracked her skull and killed herself -- there is everything explained -- the bruise on her head --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I can't believe that.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Believe it or not.  It's best for you to pretend that you do.  After all, it was you who ordered this specimen, received it here, and paid for it.  That makes you a party to murder.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But, I didn't ask him to kill.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Who would believe that?  And you know, someone else might recognize her.  She was as well known as the Castle Rock.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Here is where you must watch closely, gentleman -- closely -- it is the very heart of the matter --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Wait, Doctor -- wait!  The child's fainting.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: She's unconscious.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Pulse?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I just saw Gray.  What was he laughing at?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: He has his own idea of a joke. Perhaps his horse tickled him in the ribs.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I've just been to see Mrs. Marsh. Georgina is doing splendidly.  The incision has healed -- clean and fine -- but she doesn't seem to have any desire to walk.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: When she's ready you bring her to me -- I'll show her how.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Dr. MacFarlane, I wonder if you know what happiness you've brought those people.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: That's only our duty, Fettes -- that's the end at which we aim with all this nasty business.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I suppose one must pass through this purgatory to the heaven of being a good doctor.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: That's the way of it, Fettes.  You bring the lassie to me.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: You can't -- can't!  Stop trying to bribe her with childishness about white horses. Let the child stand and walk -- her spine's all right.  I know it's all right.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: But she must want to stand.  She must want to walk.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Confound me, the child's a cripple, of course she wants to walk.  Child, I say to you get up out of that chair and walk.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Fettes, the more things are wrong, the more we must act as if everything were right. You must do with Joseph as you did with, the street singer -- complete dissection -- a proper entry in the book --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: What do you mean, Fettes?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: I'll have no more to do with it. I'll not put my neck into the noose, not even for your sake, Dr. MacFarlane.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Don't be a fool.  One can't begin and then stop -- and because that entry of the girl's body is in your hand, you'll do as I say. As for me, I'll tend to Gray.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: What's that you say?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: The little girl -- she couldn't walk far -- the muscles are too weak -- but she did stand and she took a step or two.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I know it -- I know it -- The moment I was rid of him --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Gray -- I'm rid of him --

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: See that, Fettes?

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: A burial party -- poor people -- it's hard to bury a loved one on a rainy day when the churchyard is so cold and lonely.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Glencorse -- that's a lonely cemetery, Fettes, not a soul around for miles.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: They'll be thinking of that, too.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Tosh!  Fettes!  It's not their grief I'm worrying about -- I'm talking of our own end --

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: You've no thought of going there?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Did you think Gray was the only one who could handle a mattock and shovel?  I've had some practice in the art.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: You couldn't do that, Doctor.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: I pass up no opportunities, I've a whole course of lectures in mind for you fellows.  We'll need subjects to demonstrate. Come along.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: Why not? I must have subjects. It's the only way I can teach. It's the only way you can learn. The stupidity of the people the idiocy of their laws will not stop no -- nor will they force me to deal with such reptilian creatures as Gray. We can do our own dirty work -- and we must.

turns.speaker: FETTES
turns.text: Where shall we put it? In the back?

turns.speaker: MACFARLANE
turns.text: No room there. We'll have to set it between us.
